subject: RELIGION
catalog_description: Introduction to leading themes and concepts in the study of religions from the ancient world to the present. Course is divided into two parts: 1) what is religion? and 2) how is religion studied? A variety of religious traditions are examined as well as various theories and definitions of religion. Includes exploration of key ways in which different religions understand such social problems as violence and ideological conflict.

subject: RELIGION
catalog_description: Is the world ordered and arranged or is it a chaos? Was there a time when the universe was not? Was it generated and will it end or is it eternal and everlasting? Who made it, if anyone? Ancient and medieval stargazers contemplated these and other questions, looking to the heavens to solve riddles of existence, fate, consciousness, and beauty, and to navigate ways of being and moving in the world. Listening in on the song of the stars, this class encounters premodern religions, literatures, and the enchanted cosmos.

subject: RELIGION
descr: Gods, Monsters & Superheroes: The Beings of the Cosmos
catalog_description: The beings of the cosmos have ranged from helpful, to evil, to downright terrifying, but in all cases, said something about what it is to be human and our role in the universe. This constellation course explores the dynamic nature of these beings as students will investigate their stories, depictions, and roles and how they interact with humanity. With a concern to move beyond the dominant narratives, this class draws from ancient to present mythologies and illuminates the gender, ethical, and social considerations evident in these constructions. In a journey through these imagined realities, we will explore the existential questions of humanity as we witness communities and cultures wrestle with self-understanding and the human relationship to the cosmos and the beings who live there.

subject: RELIGION
catalog_description: This course is an introduction to the field of sport and religion. The course will focus on the examination of how sport can work as religion creating a sense of community through rituals that reinforce and maintain social bonds and collective experience. Duke University is very known for its athletic program, amazing athletes, and fandom. The Duke Blue Devil represents not only the athletes of our school, but every current student and Duke alumni. The course will use Duke's sport culture to investigate how sports work as religion creating a sense of identity and community that transcends space and time.

subject: RELIGION
descr: Mysticism of India: Spiritual Traditions of South Asia
catalog_description: This course focuses on the mystical teachings of South Asia, including Muslim, Hindu, and Sikh material. We will pay particular attention to music and poetry. Course content is primarily premodern material, with most readings being from the 1000-1600 period. All readings are in English. No background required.

subject: RELIGION
catalog_description: In what ways is media central to the creation of religious experience? How do material things channel, transduce, activate, and mediate experience, and generate the sensorial features of religious communion? In this course, we will not only examine how religion becomes mediatized. We will also explore how religious media/tion might be constitutive of the religious experience itself. We will examine media through commonsense understanding of technologies, t.v., radio, internet, social media. We'll also examine the use of print (texts) and religious art, relics, icons, 'idols'. How have ideologies connected to these conduits of religious experience, shaped religious being and belonging?

subject: RELIGION
catalog_description: This course examines the work of religious ideas—and ideas about religion—in relation to human interactions with and understandings of the environment. In recent years, the idea of the Anthropocene has abounded in both academic and popular literature. This course uses religion as a lens to examine the role of humans in both creating ecological destruction and efforts to repair and rework relationships with the natural world. We will engage with religious texts and interrogate the forces that have shaped religion under modernity, including the Reformation, the Enlightenment, and secularization. By the end of the semester, students will have deepened and nuanced their understandings of the notoriously vexed categories of religion and the Anthropocene.

subject: RELIGION
catalog_description: Introduction to Judaic civilization from its origins to modern times.

subject: RELIGION
descr: The Archaeology of Death: Ritual and Social Structure in the Ancient World
catalog_description: Historically contextualized study of how the dead 'lived' in the ancient Roman world, in funerary practices and traditions. Topics may include: funerary rituals; ritual distinctions between the space of the living and dead around cities and in the countryside; ancestor cult; monumental and not-so-monumental tombs; grave offerings and grave assemblages; public personae and funerary iconography tied to gender, age, and occupation. Course will compare death-practices between ancient Rome and other regions and periods.

subject: RELIGION
catalog_description: Examination of the major books of the New Testament, covering their contents, ethical implications, historical and social setting, authorship, date, and theology.

subject: RELIGION
catalog_description: Topics and instructors to be announced.

subject: RELIGION
catalog_description: Religion intersects with Sci-Fi in a range of topics, tropes, and themes. They both tell stories about the place of human in the universe, the meaning and purpose of life. They both deal with the nature of good and evil, illusions and reality. Whether stories where someone is looking for the Creator, questioning the meaning of life and what makes us human, to plots that rely on religious myths, tropes, and themes, and even question the nature of religious institutions, Sci-Fi has been embedded in spirituality and religion. The course Sci-Fi and Religion explores the many entanglements between religion and science fiction and invites students to reflect on these issues.

subject: RELIGION
catalog_description: Anthropological, psychological, and Religious Studies approaches to cross-cultural study of spirit possession and shamanism. Examination of in-depth case-studies and comparative works, from both literate civilizations and non-literate cultures. Engage with contemporary concerns with nature and boundaries of personhood and embodiment and their relation to leadership.

subject: RELIGION
catalog_description: This course explores the diverse realities of Muslim women's lives, from the origins of Islam to the present, through autobiographical and biographical accounts situated in their social, economic, political, and cultural contexts. The women we will encounter through textual and audiovisual materials represent a wide range of personal backgrounds, including scholars, mystics, merchants, philanthropists, poets, slavegirls, feminists, and Islamists. We will metaphorically travel across the globe and time to understand the multifarious facets of Muslim women's lived experiences.

subject: RELIGION
catalog_description: Course will cover the life, legacy, and devotion to the Prophet of Islam. No background needed. All course material in English. Course will include various sources depicting the life of Muhammad, the statements attributed to the Prophet, and also the vast legacy of devotion to the Prophet.

subject: RELIGION
catalog_description: A study of the relationship between motion pictures and religion. Focus on the comparative portrayal of organized religions; expressions of religious life; and religious topics, such as God, evil and morality, in both Western and non-Western films in which contemporary artists and intellectuals explore the challenges of modernity.

subject: RELIGION
catalog_description: A study of the relationship between motion pictures and religion. Focus on the comparative portrayal of organized religions; expressions of religious life; and religious topics, such as God, evil and morality, in both Western and non-Western films in which contemporary artists and intellectuals explore the challenges of modernity.

subject: RELIGION
descr: Sex and Gender in the Hebrew Bible
catalog_description: Women in ancient Israel, early Christianity, and early Judaism in their contexts in the Near Eastern and Greco-Roman worlds, with attention to the relation between textual depictions and social reality and to the ethical issues raised by the continuing authority of biblical texts for matters of gender. Sources include the Bible, images from art, and archaeological remains.

subject: RELIGION
catalog_description: This course explores one of the most provocative questions in modern religious thought: Is God dead? Instead of answering this question definitively, it examines how influential philosophers, theologians, and cultural critics in European and American thought have responded to the perceived reality of the death of God. Through close readings of key texts, it engages with scientific, existentialist, psychoanalytical, theological, gender, and racial perspectives on the modern religious situation, secularism, and the search for meaning in a world without an absolute foundation. The course considers whether the 'death of God' is a historical reality, a philosophical provocation, or an unfinished debate, and explores the political and moral implications of these questions.

subject: RELIGION
catalog_description: The course discusses the relationship between religion and science from four perspectives: • Religion and 'the history' of science • Religion and 'the method' of science • Religion and the 'theories' of science • 'Philosophical and theological' reflections. The focus sciences are four in addition to their metaphysical implications: • Physics (quantum theory, relativity, order and complexity) • Astronomy (the Big Bang, creation in Abrahamic religions, design, chance and necessity) • Biology (Darwinism and evolutionary theory, natural theology, and a hierarchy of levels) • Cognitive psychology & neuroscience (perception, language, problem-solving, decision-making, and brain mechanisms).

subject: RELIGION
descr: The Politics of Religion in Asia
catalog_description: Religious logics and ritual practices have been pivotal in political formations globally, and may form the hidden foundations underlying secular state authority. In Asia, rituals of state long served to legitimize and sustain kingdoms, and nation-states. Religious revivals, charismatic leaders and strongmen, ghosts, spirit mediums, amulet cults also animate people's political aspirations. How have these figured into representations of social, cultural, religious, ethnic difference in modern Asia? Students will examine complexities of theologically-inflected reasoning in Asia, to understand the hegemony of state, and inspiriting fuel that drives political movements. Ethnographies cover Korea, Vietnam, India, Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, and scholarship on Inter-Asian cultural studies.

subject: RELIGION
descr: Christian Mysticism: Esoteric and Mystical Christianity from the Ancient to the Modern World
catalog_description: Traces the history, practice, and literatures of Christian mysticism from the Jesus movement to the New Age, with particular attention to 'gnosticism,' Platonism, and the tense relationship between mysticism and orthodoxy.

subject: RELIGION
descr: Cults: New Religious Movements in America
catalog_description: Brainwashing. Fanaticism. Charismatic leaders. New ideas. Are these the ingredients of a cult? This course offers critical perspectives on what new religious movements are, why they form, and why they are marginalized in contemporary America. The course focuses particularly on the representation of so-called 'cults,' examining how gender, race, and sexuality impact cultural perceptions of new religious movements in the United States. Students in this course will use film as a medium to think about the ways 'cults' get depicted as antagonists of 'religion.' They will make their own films and reflect on the challenges of depicting religious communities that are marginalized, controversial, and wary of outsiders.

subject: RELIGION
descr: Buddhist Meditation: Cultivation Practices and Psychology
catalog_description: Buddhist paths and techniques of self-transformation in premodern and modern Buddhist cultures. Conceptions of the psychophysical person and goals of Buddhist practice assumed by these meditative techniques. Reinterpretation and modification of traditional meditation practices in contemporary Buddhist societies. Students who took this course as an 89S First Year Seminar are not eligible to enroll.

subject: RELIGION
catalog_description: The Quran as scripture; mystical poetry; stories of the early community; literary cultures in the early community; modern reinterpretations of Islamic sources; Islamist literature; modern Islamic poetry, novels, plays, and stories.

subject: RELIGION
catalog_description: Major developments in Jewish history from the early modern period to today. The Kehillah, the Spanish-Jewish Diaspora, the rise of Polish Jewry, the Safed Kabbalah, Sabbatianism, the emergence of the Chassidut, the Haskalah (Jewish Enlightenment), Emancipation and the nation state, Reform Judaism, economic modernization, racial antisemitism, Zionism, the Holocaust, the State of Israel, flourishing Jewish pluralism in the United States, the future: nation and Diaspora?

subject: RELIGION
catalog_description: Historical-critical study of early non-canonical Christian Gospels, with special reference to the Gospel of Thomas, the Gospel of Peter, the Protevangelium of James, the Infancy Gospel of Thomas, Papyrus Egerton 2, Gospel of Mary, Gospel of Judas, Gospel of Philip, Dialogue of the Savior and Secret Mark; their relationship to other early Christian texts, their view of Jesus, their place in early Christianity; questions of authority, canon, canonical-bias, and concepts of heresy and orthodoxy.

subject: RELIGION
catalog_description: This class investigates how religion shapes understandings of bodies and sex, and in turn how embodied, gendered, and queer subject positions inform religious experience. The class will begin by establishing foundational concepts of the self, body, and sexuality and investigate various understandings of religion. We will engage a range of literature from religious studies, anthropology, gender and sexuality studies, and history to interrogate assumptions that women, queer, and gender non-conforming people are necessarily marginalized by religious institutions, cosmologies, and traditions. Overall, we will investigate the ways that religion can be a site where ideas about gender and sexuality can be simultaneously imposed, performed, contested, and creatively reimagined.

subject: RELIGION
descr: The Theology and Fiction of C. S. Lewis
catalog_description: A study of texts of cultural criticism, fantasy fiction, and theological and moral argument by C. S. Lewis; their dependence on the cultural situation in which they were deployed; an engagement with the interaction of magic, science, and religion; and the reasons for their continuing force and wide appeal.

subject: RELIGION
descr: Readings in Early Christian Literature: Greek
catalog_description: Close readings of key texts in early Christian literature in the original language.

subject: RELIGION
catalog_description: Graduate level special topics in religion. Topics may include Early Christianity and Deuteronomy, among others.

subject: RELIGION
descr: The Principles of Islamic Jurisprudence (Usul al-Fiqh)
catalog_description: This course offers a comprehensive study of the principles of jurisprudence, a foundational discipline for all Islamic narrative sciences. Students examine four main areas: Language and Meaning, addressing textual interpretation; Rational Correlations, exploring the role of reason in deriving rulings; Authority, assessing valid sources of law and their evidentiary weight; and Procedural Principles, guiding legal reasoning lacking clear proof. The course combines close reading of a major original text—Arabic proficiency required—and analysis of modern English-language scholarship. Emphasis is placed on historical development, theoretical foundations, and comparative perspectives.
